question: Question 1 Suppose a program is running on a non-pipelined single processor computer system. The computer is connected to an external device that can interrupt the processor asynchronously. The processor needs to execute the interrupt service routine (ISR) to serve this interrupt. The following steps (not necessarily in order) are taken by the processor when the interrupt arrives: (i) The processor saves the content of the program counter. (ii) The program counter is loaded with the start address of the ISR. (iii) The processor finishes the present instruction. Which ONE of the following is the CORRECT sequence of steps?

question: Question 7 [latex]g(. )[/latex] is a function from [latex]A[/latex] to [latex]B[/latex], [latex]f(. )[/latex] is a function from [latex]B[/latex] to [latex]C[/latex], and their composition defined as [latex]f(g(. ))[/latex] is a mapping from [latex]A[/latex] to [latex]C[/latex]. If [latex]f(. )[/latex] and [latex]f(g(. ))[/latex] are onto (surjective) functions, which ONE of the following is TRUE about the function [latex]g(. )[/latex]?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.C: [latex]g(. )[/latex] must be a bijective function, that is, both one-to-one and onto.
options.D: [latex]g(. )[/latex] is not required to be a one-to-one or onto function.

question: Question 8 Let [latex]G[/latex] be any undirected graph with positive edge weights, and [latex]T[/latex] be a minimum spanning tree of [latex]G[/latex]. question: Question 9 Consider the following context-free grammar [latex]G[/latex], where [latex]S[/latex], [latex]A[/latex], and [latex]B[/latex] are the variables (non-terminals), [latex]a[/latex] and [latex]b[/latex] are the terminal symbols, [latex]S[/latex] is the start variable, and the rules of [latex]G[/latex] are described as: [latex]S \to aaB \mid Abb[/latex] [latex]A \to a \mid aA[/latex] [latex]B \to b \mid bB[/latex] Which ONE of the languages [latex]L(G)[/latex] is accepted by [latex]G[/latex]?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.B: [latex]L(G) = \{ a^n b^{2n} \mid n \geq 1 \} \cup \{ a^{2n} b^n \mid n \geq 1 \}[/latex]

options.B: At least one node will split and redistribute.

question: Question 13 Consider the given system of linear equations for variables [latex]x[/latex] and [latex]y[/latex], where [latex]k[/latex] is a real-valued constant. Which of the following option(s) is/are CORRECT? [latex]x + k y = 1[/latex] [latex]k x + y = -1[/latex]
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: There is exactly one value of [latex]k[/latex] for which the above system of equations has no solution.
options.B: There exist an infinite number of values of [latex]k[/latex] for which the system of equations has no solution.
options.C: There exists exactly one value of [latex]k[/latex] for which the system of equations has exactly one solution.
options.D: There exists exactly one value of [latex]k[/latex] for which the system of equations has an infinite number of solutions.

question: Question 14 Let [latex]X[/latex] be a 3-variable Boolean function that produces output as '1' when at least two of the input variables are '1'. Which of the following statement(s) is/are CORRECT, where [latex]a, b, c, d, e[/latex] are Boolean variables?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: [latex]X(a, b, X(c, d, e)) = X(X(a, b, c), d, e)[/latex]
options.B: [latex]X(a, b, X(a, b, c)) = X(a, b, c)[/latex]
options.C: [latex]X(a, b, X(a, c, d)) = (X(a, b, a) \text{ AND } X(c, d, c))[/latex]
options.D: [latex]X(a, b, c) = X(a, X(a, b, c), X(a, c, c))[/latex]

question: Question 16 Which of the following statement(s) is/are TRUE for any binary search tree (BST) having [latex]n[/latex] distinct integers?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: The maximum length of a path from the root node to any other node is [latex](n - 1)[/latex].
options.B: An inorder traversal will always produce a sorted sequence of elements.
options.C: Finding an element takes [latex]O(\log_2 n)[/latex] time in the worst case.
options.D: Every BST is also a Min-Heap.

question: Question 17 A partial data path of a processor is given in the figure, where [latex]RA[/latex], [latex]RB[/latex], and [latex]RZ[/latex] are 32-bit registers. Which option(s) is/are CORRECT related to arithmetic operations using the data path as shown?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: The data path can implement arithmetic operations involving two registers.
options.B: The data path can implement arithmetic operations involving one register and one immediate value.
options.C: The data path can implement arithmetic operations involving two immediate values.
options.D: The data path can only implement arithmetic operations involving one register and one immediate value.

question: Question 18 A regular language [latex]L[/latex] is accepted by a non-deterministic finite automaton (NFA) with [latex]n[/latex] states. Which of the following statement(s) is/are FALSE?

options.A: [latex]L[/latex] may have an accepting NFA with < [latex]n[/latex] states.
options.B: [latex]L[/latex] may have an accepting DFA with < [latex]n[/latex] states.
options.C: There exists a DFA with [latex]\leq 2^n[/latex] states that accepts [latex]L[/latex].
options.D: Every DFA that accepts [latex]L[/latex] has [latex]> 2^n[/latex] states.

question: Question 28 A computer has two processors, [latex]M_1[/latex] and [latex]M_2[/latex]. Four processes [latex]P_1, P_2, P_3, P_4[/latex] with CPU bursts of 20, 16, 25, and 10 milliseconds, respectively, arrive at the same time and these are the only processes in the system. The scheduler uses non-preemptive priority scheduling, with priorities decided as follows: [latex]M_1[/latex] uses priority of execution for the processes as, [latex]P_1 > P_3 > P_2 > P_4[/latex], i.e., [latex]P_1[/latex] and [latex]P_4[/latex] have highest and lowest priorities, respectively. [latex]M_2[/latex] uses priority of execution for the processes as, [latex]P_2 > P_3 > P_4 > P_1[/latex], i.e., [latex]P_2[/latex] and [latex]P_1[/latex] have highest and lowest priorities, respectively. A process [latex]P_i[/latex] is scheduled to a processor [latex]M_k[/latex], if the processor is free and no other process [latex]P_j[/latex] is waiting with higher priority. At any given point of time, a process can be allocated to any one of the free processors without violating the execution priority rules. Ignore the context switch time. What will be the average waiting time of the processes in milliseconds?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

question: Question 29 Consider two relations describing teams and players in a sports league: [latex]teams(tid, tname):tid, tname [/latex] are team-id and team-name, respectively [latex]players(pid, pname, tid):pid,pname,tid[/latex] denote player-id, player-name and the team-id of the player, respectively Which ONE of the following tuple relational calculus queries returns the name of the players who play for the team having name as 'MI'?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: [latex] \{ p.pname \mid p \in players \wedge \exists t ( t \in teams \wedge p.tid = t.tid \wedge t.tname = 'MI' ) \} [/latex]
options.B: [latex] \{ p.pname \mid p \in teams \wedge \exists t ( t \in players \wedge p.tid = t.tid \wedge t.tname = 'MI' ) \} [/latex]
options.C: [latex] \{ p.pname \mid p \in players \wedge \exists t ( t \in teams \wedge t.tname = 'MI' ) \} [/latex]
options.D: [latex] \{ p.pname \mid p \in teams \wedge \exists t ( t \in players \wedge t.tname = 'MI' ) \} [/latex]

question: Question 33 Let [latex]G(V, E)[/latex] be an undirected and unweighted graph with 100 vertices. Let [latex]d(u, v)[/latex] denote the number of edges in a shortest path between vertices [latex]u[/latex] and [latex]v[/latex] in [latex]V[/latex]. Let the maximum value of [latex]d(u, v)[/latex], [latex]u, v \in V[/latex] such that [latex]u \neq v[/latex], be 30. Let [latex]T[/latex] be any breadth-first-search tree of [latex]G[/latex]. Which ONE of the given options is CORRECT for every such graph [latex]G[/latex]?

options.C: The height of [latex]T[/latex] is at least 15.
options.D: The height of [latex]T[/latex] is at least 30.

question: Question 34 Consider the following two languages over the alphabet [latex]\{a, b\}[/latex]: [latex]L_1 = \{ \alpha \beta \alpha \mid \alpha \in \{a, b\}^+ \text{ and } \beta \in \{a, b\}^+ \}[/latex] [latex]L_2 = \{ \alpha \beta \alpha \mid \alpha \in \{a\}^+ \text{ and } \beta \in \{a, b\}^+ \}[/latex] Which ONE of the following statements is CORRECT?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.B: [latex]L_1[/latex] is a regular language but [latex]L_2[/latex] is not a regular language.
options.C: [latex]L_1[/latex] is not a regular language but [latex]L_2[/latex] is a regular language.
options.D: Neither [latex]L_1[/latex] nor [latex]L_2[/latex] is a regular language.

question: Question 35 Consider the following two languages over the alphabet [latex]\{a, b, c\}[/latex], where [latex]m[/latex] and [latex]n[/latex] are natural numbers: [latex]L_1 = \{ a^m b^m c^{m+n} \mid m, n \geq 1 \}[/latex] [latex]L_2 = \{ a^m b^n c^{m+n} \mid m, n \geq 1 \}[/latex] Which ONE of the following statements is CORRECT?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.B: [latex]L_1[/latex] is a context-free language but [latex]L_2[/latex] is not a context-free language.
options.C: [latex]L_1[/latex] is not a context-free language but [latex]L_2[/latex] is a context-free language.

question: Question 36 Which of the following statement(s) is/are TRUE while computing [latex]First[/latex] and [latex]Follow[/latex] during top-down parsing by a compiler?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: For a production [latex]A \to \epsilon ,  \epsilon [/latex] will be added to [latex]First(A) [/latex].
options.B: If there is any input right end marker, it will be added to[latex] First(S) [/latex], where [latex] S [/latex] is the start symbol.
options.C: For a production [latex] A \to \epsilon,  \epsilon [/latex] will be added to [latex] Follow(A) [/latex].
options.D: If there is any input right end marker, it will be added to [latex] Follow(S) [/latex], where [latex] S [/latex] is the start symbol.

question: Question 37 Consider a relational schema [latex] team(name, city, owner) [/latex], with functional dependencies  [latex]\{ name \to city [/latex], [latex] name \to owner \} [/latex] . The relation [latex] team [/latex] is decomposed into two relations, [latex] t_1(name, city) [/latex] and [latex] t_2(name, owner) [/latex]. Which of the following statement(s) is/are TRUE?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: The relation [latex] team [/latex] is NOT in BCNF.
options.B: The relations [latex] t_1 [/latex] and [latex] t_2 [/latex] are in BCNF.
options.C: The decomposition constitutes a lossless join.

question: Question 38 Which of the following predicate logic formulae/formula is/are CORRECT representation(s) of the statement: "Everyone has exactly one mother"? The meanings of the predicates used are: [latex]mother(y,x): y[/latex] is the mother of [latex] x [/latex] [latex]noteq(x,y): x[/latex] and  [latex] y [/latex] are not equal
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: [latex] \forall x \exists y \exists z (mother(y, x) \land \neg mother(z, x)) [/latex]
options.B: [latex] \forall x \exists y [mother(y, x) \land \forall z (noteq(z, y) \to \neg mother(z, x))] [/latex]
options.C: [latex] \forall x \forall y [mother(y, x) \to \exists z (mother(z, x) \land \neg noteq(z, y))] [/latex]
options.D: [latex] \forall x \exists y [mother(y, x) \land \neg \exists z (noteq(z, y) \land mother(z, x))] [/latex]

question: Question 61 "I put the brown paper in my pocket along with the chalks, and possibly other things. I suppose everyone must have reflected how primeval and how poetical are the things that one carries in one's pocket: the pocket-knife, for instance the type of all human tools, the infant of the sword. Once I planned to write a book of poems entirely about the things in my pocket. But I found it would be too long: and the age of the great epics is past." (From G.K. Chesterton's "A Piece of Chalk") Based only on the information provided in the above passage, which one of the following statements is true?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: The author of the passage carries a mirror in his pocket to reflect upon things.
options.B: The author of the passage had decided to write a poem on epics.
options.C: The pocket-knife is described as the infant of the sword.
options.D: Epics are described as too inconvenient to write.
